children.subject: Though I don't know if the weightage for the different assignments (HW, exams, project) has changed since then.

The project was released ~3 days ago; I have 100% on all the homeworks.

I double-checked, and I'm slightly below average (like -0.2 SD). On berkeleytime, it seems like you need to be in the 60th percentile for an A- (0.25 SD).

I would assume that most people have 100% on the homeworks, I don't think the grade weightages have changed from last semester,

Well last semester there was a legit curve to each and every HW, with a lot of people losing a fair amount of points on each HW (Averages would range anywhere from 65-85%). Not sure if this is the case this semester. As for you being -0.2 below (on each midterm, or just one?), I think you can make that up with the project, the average for which is between 3-4% out of 5% (or at least that's what I believe it was last semester), if you score 5/5, which is definitely doable even if you're otherwise average in the class. Which then brings us to the last factor, the final. The final's tough, on everyone, irrespective of whether they did well on midterms or not. So you're just gonna have to work on that end and try and be 0.2-0.3 or so SD above. 

Also I'm not sure which professor said a single B+ on your transcript is going to reflect poorly for grad school, but that doesn't sound completely right to me. I think it is most important to have relevant research experience, and a good GPA helps you get that as an undergrad, and a single B+ shouldn't really dent that. But you should ask others more experienced than me about this kind of thing.

How are you doing on the HWs? And have you started the project? Last semester, I realized (via a few data points) that if one did average across all exams and did pretty well on the HWs + project, one could probably eke out an A-

history.content: I don't think the grade of 1 particular class will have any impact on your grad apps

children.subject: @student answerer, OP here. I also thought that 1 B+ wouldn't matter, but the professor I spoke with said that a B+ in 170 might matter more, since it's a "required" upper div that's applicable in most fields of CS.
170 is quite useless though... Why take it again lol, assumed you've already learnt greedy and DP.
Right now I'm not really sure - potentially data-related things, comp bio, AI, networking.
What are you interested in doing PhD in? Some fields it may matter, others not so much so.

Overall B+ is fine.

Quotes from a professor from USCD:

GPA: warning sign if too low, but usually don't care. It's rare that someone with strong research credentials has a dangerously low GPA, and even if that were the case, I wouldn't care much. A high GPA from a highly-selective university is a slight positive signal, though.

http://www.pgbovine.net/PhD-application-tips.htm

history.content: Current sophomore here interested in doing a PhD. I did around average on both midterms, so I pretty much have a B+ now, and I don't know if I can do well enough on the final to bring it up to at least an A-. I am considering using my late drop for this class. I spoke to a faculty member about this, and he/she said that it's a bit risky applying to PhD programs with a B+ in 170 (since it's a core upper div). Is it worth using my late drop for this class, knowing that I will definitely have to take it again later? I'm planning on doing 127+189 next sem, and doing 170 the semester after that (if it makes any difference).
history.subject: B+ in CS 170 for grad school?
